content.content: It has been a year since I was just about to leave my job as the Global Legal Counsel at the Maker Foundation. Back then, I was very concerned about how MakerDAO would handle legal and regulatory topics moving forward. A month before my departure, in June 2021, I published a forum post about what I considered the regulatory topics of most importance. That’s one of my main thoughts and messages to the community back then:    Mapping out policy challenges and opportunities for Maker   To put it simply, it is not enough to survive and avoid regulatory scrutiny. To grow and outcompete traditional finance, Maker will need sophisticated regulatory thinking embedded in its overall strategy.   Unfortunately, not much has happened since then. Regulatory thinking at MakerDAO is driven almost purely by news headlines, and the recent drama on discord around Tornado Cash sanctions is just an example. MakerDAO is reactive, underinformed, sometimes ignorant, and generally susceptible to superficial analyses. Rare counterexamples like SES legal research do not change the overall picture. Are we seriously thinking about triggering some tectonic shifts in the economic structure of Dai and the Maker Protocol based on hearsay legal views? Don’t worry; I didn’t come here to rant only. I wanted to present my perspective on some legal topics relevant to the current discussions. These are just my (quickly written) thoughts and not legal advice to anyone. It is also not an exclusive list (far from it). Disclaimer: I do not represent anyone and anyone’s interests but just myself. I own MKR, but I appreciate my reputation and integrity more than my bags. Accordingly, I would like to see Maker continuing to be a respected, invincible, invulnerable, world-changing project more than any financial gains. Also, I don’t have anything against anons, but the invasion of anon accounts here has become unbearable, so I may decide not to engage in discussion with them. Here are the relevant topics: 1.	Dai regulation Tl;dr any asset which pegs to fiat currency will be strictly regulated. Any issuer of such stablecoins will be regulated and licensed. Dai and Maker will be outlawed if they don’t follow the requirements. These regulations will be very difficult to comply with without a centralized structure in place. This is the most important topic and yet the most overlooked one. Stablecoin regulations are being cooked all around the globe. In some cases (EU), they are actually ready. Many follow the thinking pattern, "when there is something certain, we will deal with that.” That fallacy inevitably leads to panic when something finally happens; see Tornado Cash and sanctions. It is sure what is going to happen. Until 2020, one of the strategies I was pursuing in the Foundation was trying to “fly under the radar” and allow the policymakers to regulate centralized stablecoins while not sticking our neck out too much. I dropped this approach after I was invited to a closed meeting of the Financial Stability Board, which consists of senior central bankers and regulators and coordinates global financial regulation. I came out from meetings and dinner with these folks, realizing they would want to have a global, all-encompassing, strict regulatory regime for any stablecoins. That was 2.5 years ago. In the meantime, the FSB issued its report confirming the approach, and individual countries started implementing their regimes largely based on FSB’s recommendations. One of the central premises of the stablecoin regulation, as implemented almost everywhere, is that it usually defines stablecoins as assets that in any form peg to a fiat currency. The exact nature of the peg does not matter. Especially after the UST collapse, one should not expect regulatory differentiation between centralized and decentralized stablecoins. In some places like the US, the debate is ongoing, but please be realistic about it. Long story short, recently Nikolai and Rune explained how the USD peg inevitably leads to the dependence on USD-denominated assets. The same applies on the regulatory front: a fiat currency peg will soon trigger rigid regulations. One difference is that it’s not only about the US regulations (a peg to USD will still trigger the EU regulations, for instance). Maker is enjoying the last months of the unregulated stablecoin wild west, but these times will be essentially over in 2023-24. I am not arguing either way, but Maker should either maintain the fiat currency peg and prepare for complex and centralizing regulations (perhaps impossible to comply with in some cases) or work out an alternative. 2.	RWA Tl;dr RWAs will bring regulatory troubles and costs on Maker. I’ve been involved in RWAs since the early days. In 2017, just before joining Maker later that year, I was part of a German startup that was tokenizing equity. I was one of the persons working on RWAs in the Foundation when the topic first seriously emerged in 2018. In 2020-21, I led a side project that built a solution for decentralized security token trading and received the EU law green light from a regulator. I don’t believe in RWAs in Maker. More specifically, I believe in small-scale diversification of collateral (let’s say <5%) and RWA experimentation. However, counting on RWA as the main bet and a cure for all Maker’s problems, the primary collateral source, and the source of decentralization (by that definition, almost any bank would be decentralized) was a misconception a few years ago, and it still is a misconception in 2022. The main reasons are that RWAs erode decentralization (which is not appreciated by the users until it is; see TC and Genesis cases) and, even more importantly, that in the current form, they remove the transparency, hence stripping away the critical competitive advantages of Maker. Do we really want to see news articles about “what’s actually backing Dai and what’s in the newest reserve report” like the ones about Tether or USDC? That’s not my point here, though. I want to clarify that the legal topics around RWAs are not limited to structuring the deals, which proves difficult enough by the way. Focus on RWAs will inevitably lead to regulatory burdens and troubles, particularly difficult to comply with by a DAO. This is shadow banking business under a pirate flag. Even if we finally sort out all the current issues in 1-2-3 years, the costs to comply with financial regulations will be enormous. 3.	Sanctions and AML/KYC Tl;dr do not enter panic mode over TC. Focus on solving the fundamental problems I mention in this post. Let me keep this one short as there are a lot of discussions elsewhere—just two thoughts. OFAC designation of Tornado Cash was directly related to its use in cybercrime. It’s another chapter in the ongoing war against mixers and anonymity-enhancing solutions in general. The Maker Protocol does not have much to do with these. I do not think a similar thing happening to Maker’s smart contracts is probable. That said, of course, USDC freezing/blocking is a risk. This risk is, however, associated with the inherent censorship risks of RWAs rather than a direct sanctions risk for Maker. This risk is not new and is just one of many other ones (e.g., counterparty risk). This risk should be accounted for and mitigated. For example, Maker is the largest USDC user (3.5 billion USDC) and should not be treated at par with a random 10k USDC holder and Tornado Cash user. There is, however, a real risk associated with the development of AML/KYC regulation. We will see further attacks on self-hosted wallets and forcing KYC everywhere. Maker should double down on its public policy and lobbying efforts in this area. 4.	Decentralization / DeFi regulation I will keep this one even shorter to not make this post totally indigestible, but I can elaborate later if needed. Ultimately, decentralization is and will be our strongest moat against regulatory risks. It is easy to downplay the inefficiencies it brings, but it is of great protective value, not to mention other benefits. We should treat it with care. The fact that regulators are targeting decentralized protocols like Tornado Cash should not make us think differently—this is the only thing that gives TC a chance to survive. The same thing applies to other decentralized protocols, including Maker. These are my quick thoughts. Happy to discuss.

jacek:  work out an alternative   Thank you for sharing your thoughts. Much appreciated. With regards to an alternative, in your opinion and only your personal opinion (Not legal or Financial Advice), what is the alternative? To allow DAI to become a free-floating medium of exchange?

I agree with much of this. Maker cannot be reactive and must be proactive.     jacek:  any asset which pegs to fiat currency will be strictly regulated. Any issuer of such stablecoins will be regulated and licensed. Dai and Maker will be outlawed if they don’t follow the requirements.   This is correct and many people simply do not want to think about this. This is coming and unless Maker wishes to be an outlier the conversations need to happen and action must be taken.
Maker will get outlawed then because it won’t have a backdoor or be a CBDC.

jacek:  Maker should either maintain the fiat currency peg and prepare for complex and centralizing regulations (perhaps impossible to comply with in some cases) or work out an alternative.   This is what the current discussions are about, as far as I can tell.     jacek:  MakerDAO is reactive, underinformed, sometimes ignorant, and generally susceptible to superficial analyses. Rare counterexamples like SES legal research do not change the overall picture.   I agree wholeheartedly. We have great people working behind the scenes. Let’s not panic and focus on the business. More than enough to do here.
flipflopflapdelegate:  To allow DAI to become a free-floating medium of exchange?   What about become a peg to a basket of currencies? Like pegged to the index of the top 5 global currencies.

Well thats exactly what I said just 100 times more eloquently presented. Dai will fail to comply with the regulatory requirements that will be put forth. Investment in US Bonds and RWA will make Dai vulnerable to US government regulations. Stablecoin backing needs to be reduced and Maker needs to decentralize even more. I certainly agree with all of your points. Dai should change focus. The crypto economy needs a decentralized uncensorable liquid stablecoin. Also stable collateral does not produce income whatsoever for Maker. Think about ways to reduce stablecoin backing to managable levels. Cap centralized stable collateral to 5% of the total Dai supply. Maker needs to be anti fragile to survive.

As an active RWA partner/borrower, and deeply invested in the success and stability of DAI for the long term, I believe the DAO needs to take a  look at having some centralized components, perhaps its one of the metaDAO structures. There will be some regulation, likely a patchwork of regulation around the world, and being a stablecoin, whether its pegged to 1 currency or a basket, will inevitably, at some point in not too distant future, face regulatory oversight. Being in compliance may not be too difficult or too onerous, and some jurisdictions already have DAO-friendly laws on their books, but it will require some centralization, an entity, which will be responsible for maintaining that compliance. In my opinion, this will likely to be the case with or without RWA.

Ber10:  Well thats exactly what I said just 100 times more eloquently presented. Dai will fail to comply with the regulatory requirements that will be put forth. Investment in US Bonds and RWA will make Dai vulnerable to US government regulations.   RWA investments should remain <5% or less, they require the most effort and are great for PR but also bring the most risks to the protocol. US/International bonds should remain a strategy as a way to monetize assets (we are not making any money from organic DAI and therefore not able to pay DSR), especially if they can bring them onchain via tokenization which does not seem possible for RWA investments or at least not in the 3-5 year roadmap.

flipflopflapdelegate:  what is the alternative? To allow DAI to become a free-floating medium of exchange?    Peg to something else, but be careful what exactly; this will likely not work:      TRUEMAKER:  What about become a peg to a basket of currencies? Like pegged to the index of the top 5 global currencies.    Sovereign monetary policy with no peg Consider an actual soft peg where the fiat currency is just a reference point (just an idea, I haven’t consider it closely)

rspa:  This is what the current discussions are about, as far as I can tell.   That’s great, but I haven’t seen anyone mentioning the impact of the currently changing regulatory landscape—and this is a crucial aspect for deciding on maintaining vs. dropping the USD peg.
Centrifuge has brought RWA on-chain.
No way! Thats huge.

This is very good and has a lot of great advice for the community. In respect to point 2 below, as General Counsel for Centrifuge, I would say that RWA is a big category of assets and there are lots of different ways to use these as Maker collateral. Some of these work better than others. We think that Centrifuge has solved a number of the issues you have highlighted under 2:     jacek:  RWAs erode decentralization   This should not be the case and is not the case for the Maker vault integration with the Centrifuge pools. There are methods and practices that can avoid creating centralization and still use RWAs as collateral in a secure manner.     jacek:  in the current form, they remove the transparency, hence stripping away the critical competitive advantages of Maker   We also do not agree with this. There is no need to give up any transparency in regard to using RWAs as collateral. The Centrifuge protocol supports transparency so the community can track RWA collateral in real-time.     jacek:  Focus on RWAs will inevitably lead to regulatory burdens and troubles, particularly difficult to comply with by a DAO.   I would also disagree on this point. In fact, I would argue just the opposite. Investments in Centrifuge pools are in full compliance with securities laws. Our pools are permissioned with all investors checked for AML and sanctions purposes. There is far more potential regulatory risk with using stablecoins as collateral or cryptoassets such as ETH where wallets can be blocked or frozen and liquidity can disappear overnight due to fear of regulatory action.

Agree with all of your assessments including this important one:     jacek:  Also, I don’t have anything against anons, but the invasion of anon accounts here has become unbearable, so I may decide not to engage in discussion with them.   Don’t feed the trolls. I want to reiterate your first most important point.     jacek:  1. Dai regulation Tl;dr any asset which pegs to fiat currency will be strictly regulated. Any issuer of such stablecoins will be regulated and licensed. Dai and Maker will be outlawed if they don’t follow the requirements. These regulations will be very difficult to comply with without a centralized structure in place.   Can’t agree with this more and it is one of the most under appreciated and misunderstood by MakerDAO. With respect to RWA.     jacek:  Tl;dr RWAs will bring regulatory troubles and costs on Maker.   Absolutely.   I am going to plug for a post I made regarding RWA, USDC basically bringing significant kind of centralization.     Offloading growing Centralization risks to Maker and to DAI. Opening a general discussion Risk       Hello MakerDAO  While I have been working on things in the background.   I have not made much progress and there are a number of concerns springing up that I think are capturing attention but not getting significant traction.  With this post I hope to lay out the issues and to present for discussion what I see as the issues that lay underneath the issues.  Primary issue:  Maker collateral custody centralization.  USDC, wBTC, USDP each account for over 500M worth of collateral.   As far as I know…     One of my favorite lines that really describes Maker.     jacek:  This is shadow banking business under a pirate flag.   One of the vast number of important reasons I put forward my Maker3.0 proposal Proposal: Maker3.0 - The future of crypto lending. (RFC) was to try to firewall Maker2.0 and $$ pegged DAI so that one Maker could focus to work towards compliance while funding research into Maker3.0 and DAI3 (not pegged to USD).   My analysis in the end suggests that all crypto comes under compliance ‘white’, or basically goes ‘black’.   DAI3 by going away from a hard currency peg of any kind and seeking to build a completely new protocol and DAI3 could buy some amount of time but AML/KYC compliance I think is going to overshadow everything leading to real issues in the space. Great quotes from you I consider really important:     jacek:  Maker should double down on its public policy and lobbying efforts in this area.   Critical and I will add DeFI needs to focus not just on lobbying but also education.  Really a working group needs to be formed and funded to try to build rails towards a vision of the future that legislators and regulators can get on board with.  But based on other statements it looks like a lot of work has already been done, and it perhaps is likely legislative, regulatory minds are already made up (crypto must follow TradFI even if TradFI launders $1T/yr 99% unhindered)     jacek:  Ultimately, decentralization is and will be our strongest moat against regulatory risks. It is easy to downplay the inefficiencies it brings, but it is of great protective value, not to mention other benefits   Personally I think this whole ‘decentralized’ issue is going to fall by wayside once regulations finally bite.  It will not matter if you are a decentralized protocol if you don’t follow laws once a sanction is applied and backed by full punishment of the law.  People don’t really have a choice if the choice is to break or not break the law, particularly if the off ramps are going to block based on wallet blacklisting connections.   I honestly don’t have a great answer to how DeFI can live in TradFI in any other way than by following all jurisdictional laws (in all jurisdictions btw) which places some significant constraints on DeFI that are much greater than TradFI btw. Really appreciate the well thought out post and much of your points follow results of my own analysis, both of recent times and up to almost 8-10 years ago now. I think I only have one question. If you thought of MakerDAO having to deal with any single issue, which one is would the least amount of effort yield the greatest results (DAI and regulation or sanctions and AML/KYC) or something else?

Thank you for prompting this discussion here.  I would add a few issues for consideration on this thread. Disclaimer - these are a rough outline of concerns that shouldn’t be taken as advice.  You should discuss any legal questions you have about the MakerDAO ecosystem or any other legal issues with your counsel. Most of my commentary is also from a US perspective, I hope others can weigh in on these and similar concerns from an international perspective (keeping in mind that the US does have a lot of extra-territorial regulatory influence). DAO Entity Status There is an underlying assumption by the community at large that the DAO has no legal entity status.  This assumption is untested, and there is activity from regulators that suggests it might be wrong.  Most notably is the SEC’s Report and Recommendation on the DAO: https://www.sec.gov/litigation/investreport/34-81207.pdf Therein, the SEC asserts that the DAO is an “unincorporated organization” and that “[t]he DAO was ‘responsible for the success or failure of the enterprise,’ and accordingly, was the entity about which investors needed information material to their investment decision.” Id. at 16.  So at least the SEC believes that DAOs are (or can be) legal entities subject to US securities law.  We have also seen private parties bring litigation against DAOs.  See, e.g., Sarcuni et al v. bZx DAO et al., Case No. 3:22-cv-618-LAB-DEB (Complaint) (“bZx protocol purports to be a so-called DAO, or decentralized autonomous organization, that lacks any legal formalities or recognition.  There is another phrase in American law for that kind of arrangement: general partnership.  That means each of the partners is jointly and severally liable to the Plaintiffs and must make good on the full amount of its debts.”) (emphasis in original). Likewise, we have even seen MakerDAO itself threatened with a patent infringement lawsuit: Infringement of TRS's U.S. Patent No. 10,025,797 by MakerDao NB: I am not commenting on the merits of these cases, just that the concern is one that has to be taken seriously. If an entity does exist, additional questions include what kind of entity (state unincorporated association?  General partnership? Something else?), who the members are (all token holders? All forum members?  Core Unit Facilitators? Delegates? Shadow Delegates? Folks that voted their tokens?) , what obligations DAO members have to eachother, what where the entity is subject to jurisdiction, what taxes does it (and it’s members) owe? Securities Treatment of MakerDAO Related Digital Assets Another key topic is what legal kind of assets are related to and issued by the MakerDAO protocol.  The fight is typically framed as a question of whether particular assets are “commodities” or “securities.”  At a high level, lots of crypto enthusiasts want tokens to be considered “commodities” which would be regulated by the CFTC; they have authority over, but (with some exceptions, especially regarding fraud) don’t restrict “spot” trading of commodities.  Securities, on the other hand, are subject to a lot of restrictions on issuance, registration, sale, etc. by the SEC.  This is in part why RWA transactions have to involve a broker/dealer like Genesis. This determination has obvious implications for MKR, and Dai tokens, but this can also have potential implications for CDP’s, Vaults, or anything else that is tokenized.  And not all tokens will necessarily be treated the same way. Again, the Report on the DAO is one of the best official sources explaining the position of the SEC on this.  See also SEC.gov | Framework for “Investment Contract” Analysis of Digital Assets.  The Hinman Speech is a good overview for non-lawyers on some of the key concepts, but the SEC is now trying to disclaim this in the Ripple litigation. SEC.gov | Digital Asset Transactions: When Howey Met Gary (Plastic).  All of these sources reference the Howey test articulated in a 1946 Supreme Court case.  SEC v. WJ Howey Co., 328 US 293 - Supreme Court 1946 - Google Scholar.  The BlockFi case has also highlighted the importance of the Reves test.  https://www.sec.gov/litigation/admin/2022/33-11029.pdf Although they’ve gotten less attention, other important issues include:  Securitization of digital assets–if you pledge digital assets to secure a loan, then transfer them without permission, lender may (or may not) be able to go after the third-party transferee to reclaim them, depending on state law. Bankruptcy–lately, this has been an issue for CeFi exchanges, with users frustrated that they may be treated as unsecured creditors rather than secured creditors with a claim on their crypto deposits.  But this could also become an issue in DeFi; imagine if a vault holder declares bankruptcy–are keepers that move to liquidate their vault breaching the automatic stay?  What if the USD peg breaks and Dai is undercollateralized and a user files an involuntary bankruptcy petition against MakerDAO; is there an obligation to institute an emergency freeze? Money transmission–in addition to OFAC, FinCEN has fined a handful for prominent crypto firms for engaging in money transmission without a money transmitter license, or failing to keep KYC/AML records.  There are also state regimes to consider.  – Stepping back to your comments, I very much agree that we need long term and not reactionary thinking.  I also want to see Maker continue to be a respected and important part of not only the DeFi ecosystem, but the world more broadly. I have some skepticism of your analysis of the coming stablecoin regime.  My read on proposes US regulation is not that anything pegged to a Fiat currency must comply with a forthcoming regulatory regime for stabelcoins.  Rather, the Lumis-Gillibrand bill limits “Payment Stablecoin” digital assets “redeemable, on demand, on a one-to-one basis for instruments … defined as legal tender under section 5103…” which Dai, even considering the PSM, is not (USDC is not defined as legal tender). https://www.gillibrand.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/Lummis-Gillibrand%20Responsible%20Financial%20Innovation%20Act%20[Final].pdf.  We’re still waiting for the text of the Boozman-Staenow bill, but my secondhand understanding of discussions with staffers is that it would only capture redeemable stablecoins, and not algorithmic or collateralized stablecoins like Dai.  Further, the Lumis-Gillibrand bill would likely push Dai towards being treated as a commodity (though the new regulatory framework for “ancillary assets” still does not perfectly fit the Maker Ecosystem).  But these bills could also be bad for Maker if Treasury and the SEC decide that the passage of a regulatory framework for stablecoins means its open season to make life hell for any nonconforming coins. I pretty much agree with the rest of the factual information you present, but I’m not sure I understand the conclusion you reach.  You agree that trying to fly under the radar is not a viable strategy, but seem to be against anything that leads to engagement with regulators.  I am not sure how this is a viable strategy.  Maybe regulators can’t touch the protocol itself, but the IRS, SEC, Treasury, DOJ, and swath of state regulators (and I would assume European regulators) can make life hard for the users of the protocol. I also think there is a third option between full regulator compliance and centralization vs. outright defiance.  The SEC wants to make law that will serve them well, and to do that, they are likely to litigate against underfinanced, unsympathetic defendants, that judges won’t hesitate to bring the hammer down on.  But web3 entities with a sheen of legitimacy, that don’t hurt consumers, are less likely to be regulatory targets.  It reminds me of a joke:  a couple guys are walking in the forest and see a vicious bear that starts heading towards them.  The first guy immediately takes a knee and starts tightening his shoelaces.  The second guy shouts, “you’re crazy!  You’ll never outrun the bear!” The first guy replies: “I don’t have to outrun the bear, I just have to outrun you.”  A bunch of DeFi projects are eventually going to fall, as regulation drives away capital.  To not get caught and become one of these projects, the Maker community should proactively respond to regulators, dismantling their legal case before they can bring it. The harder question for me to answer is “how does the community do that.”  I don’t have a fully fleshed out idea.  And I don’t think the answer can or should be “relaunch with a blacklist.” But it might involve creating some sort of entities similar to what RWF has been doing to be the point of contact for regulated entities and individuals concerned about regulation.  And in the long term, Dai needs to grow broad enough in adoption that it would be so disruptive to shut it down as to be politically infeasible.

Great post! Look at what angry people are doing now to protest the Tornado Cash sanctions.   twitter.com    ElBarto_Crypto @ElBarto_Crypto  Six degrees of tornado cash is a thing. Even crazier, while only 0.03% of addresses received ETH from tornado cash, almost half the entire ETH network is only two hops from a tornado cash receiver. https://t.co/LDU9g0r7tQ   12:21 PM - 13 Aug 2022           530                130              twitter.com    OKHotshot @NFTherder  Aave and Uniswap are now blocking wallets that received 0.1E from an unknown Tornado Cash protester following the US sanctions  Even though you may've NEVER agreed to receiving TC funds any interaction with TC may get your wallet blocked from these (and future) dapps https://t.co/sDXUnc4bg0    1:53 AM - 14 Aug 2022           74                19            Things like this just show the world that this space is like the wild west and some type of compliance is inevitable for survival. Unfortunately, in the U.S., the chances of meaningful proposed legislation actually becoming law in 2022 is slim to none. I personally feel that DAOs will be targets in the interim.
Truly cold yet accurate analysis. Thank you, Luca

0xbocaJ:  A bunch of DeFi projects are eventually going to fall, as regulation drives away capital. To not get caught and become one of these projects, the Maker community should proactively respond to regulators, dismantling their legal case before they can bring it.   Good post with some nice detail and investigation @0xbocaJ I disagree with the above.   While I think engagement with regulators should be undertaken as a show of good faith, I think engagement to “dismantle their legal case before they can bring it” isn’t a viable strategy.  In fact engaging in this fashion will likely put the individual or entity right smack in the line of litigation. Also as others have commented @GFXlabs the likely approach here to deal with a DAO is to treat DAO’s as general partnerships and basically go after the weakest links. I also think the treatment of the issuance of the DAOs (various Tokens they issue) vs. the DAOs themselves creates a greater surface area for regulatory litigation. There are many deep issues to consider here.   One of them is this idea a lot of people have that Maker and DAI be committed to being decentralized and this somehow saves everything from being attacked.  I dispute this assertion and would counter that as @GFXlabs has suggested Maker rapidly figure out the most favorable jurisdiction to home in and then work out all the details of international regulatory compliance ‘from that jurisdiction’.   Anything short of doing this basically opens the DAO up to the application of ALL regulatory laws, across ALL jurisdictions on each and every party in said jurisdiction. Short of legislators coming around to an idea that a network in effect becomes its own jurisdiction (like it’s own nation state) or some similar special treatment of blockchain networks (both of these treatments highly unlikely to come to pass imo) in absence of a jurisdiction and a legal entity to go with it regulators and legislators are likely to treat DAOs and associated digital assets as they do all other threats to their sovereignty and citizenry. Which is why I have been suggesting that DeFI projects organize and fund a collective to both propose a global legal framework for the space, and then educate and lobby regulators to implement some form of  proposed organizational/leal model internationally.   Anything short of this will leave the space constantly battling on one or more fronts.

The icewater team has spent several years researching and developing methods of stabilization that do not depend on fiat peg (or peg to any external commodity). The key is to use interest rates. I would be happy to work with Maker to explore a way to implement something like this, as I think it is essential to the future of truly decentralized crypto.
Wyoming provides a DAO-friendly jurisdiction in the US Wyoming LLC as a DAO Legal Wrapper: What You Need to Know

Yes and it has been tweaked based upon critiques, which is common with new legislation. Wyoming launches Chancery Court, updates DAO laws This article, which seems to be authored by a law student, also makes some good points regarding the original bill.    ipjournal.law.wfu.edu   Wyoming Built a Home for DAOs—Why They Won’t Come | Journal of Business &... By: Joshua Durham  Wyoming’s so-called “slack-jawed” Decentralized Autonomous Organizations “(DAO”) Supplement bill will take effect July 2021. It grants DAOs the opportunity to register as limited liability companies (“LLCs”) in the state. This bill...

Either we choose or live in limbo. The community is divided on the two points listed below. Our time to decide is shrinking. We should proactively try to assess which direction to take, at this point the direction is less important than actually deciding because if we do nothing we are left in a vulnerable and stressful situation. No-fee PSM Growing DAI adoption and becoming >100B market cap stablecoin giant. At this point, blanket regulation, blacklisting vault addresses and sanctioning DAI holders would be off limits. The impact of trying to contain DAI would create a major community backlash and if its peg and tradability are “messed” with its ripple effects would impact the entire financial system. Continuing with a no-fee PSM strategy can enable fast growth but its yet to be determined if stablecoin inflows will remain strong in a bull market. To combat a potential slowdown, an attractive yield would be required. To do so, with lower recurring revenues and a stagnant asset allocation situation, the protocol might run at a loss (all else equal).  This strategy is attractive growth-oriented folks but seems to risky and unnatural to decentralization focused folks Censor-resistant Reducing reliance on USDC, RWAs and Bond strategies by setting concentration limits on non-decentralized and censor enabling products. As mentioned on this post, we can not continue to grow PSM/USDC/RWA balances while also investing in USD bonds and expect to fly under the radar of US regulators. Sooner or later they will find find a way to regulate the industry but I would bet they act sooner given stablecoins fast growth and concerns around UST collapse. To build a censor and regulation resistant coin means to set concentration limits or even off-board products. Both routes, concentration and offboarding, would require major internal shifts and actions. The strategies can leverage bracketing fees to make it uneconomical to go above our self-imposed limit. E.g. USDC collateral should be <10% at all times, then USDC-PSM is set to no-fee until 10% of DAI is backed by USDC and any trade above would have a 5% fee. There are pros and cons for both strategies and its not clear which one has more support, it would be great to have MKR leaders have facilitated debates about which direction the DAO will go in. Until a clear winner is decided, we are vulnerable to censorship and falling behind for mass adoption.

I think we’re close to the same idea here. To be clear, I’m not suggesting that we engage with regulators in a hostile fashion (at least where we can avoid it); rather, that one of the happy consequences of setting up an entity that is responsive to regulatory concerns is that it weakens the conclusory analysis that could otherwise be used against the Maker community as a whole. For example, if there is a regulated entity with a BD relationship that the initial issuance of Dai is flowing through, it’s harder (though not impossible) to say that there is an unauthorized securities issuance. (Plus all the other arguments about why Dai is not a security etc.) Having a centralized entity can also shield the community more generally from the sorts of allegations that they are a general partnership. Picking a favorable jurisdiction for incorporation, as you suggest, could be a big part of engagement, as I was using that term. I also think that while we should absolutely be concerned about the general partnership question, because its a critical risk to anyone with substantial capital, I don’t think it’s a foregone conclusion that legal entity status for the DAO necessarily means its a partnership with unlimited liability for all members. First of all, the common law requirement for a partnership is an agreement amongst all partners to carry on a business for profit.  Except for recognized delegates, I’m not aware of a generalized group of community members who have taken any sort of agreement with each other.  And as for delegates, none of what’s contained in their code of conduct agreement necessitates an obligation to carry out the business for profit.  Likewise, discussion of metaDAOs, environmental concerns, clean money, freedom of speech, and other topics demonstrates the non-financial motives driving many of the community members. Second, at least in California, there’s a difference between an unincorporated association and a general partnership liability.  This is nuanced, but for some background reading, see Cal. Corp. Code Sec. 18260 (“A money judgment against an unincorporated association, whether organized for profit or not, may be enforced only against the property of the association.”); Security-First National Bank v. Cooper, 62 Cal. App. 2d 653 (“The liability of the members of an unincorporated association on contracts 667*667 made by it varies according to the answer to the question whether the association is one organized for profit.”)  There’s also a whole century of case law dealing with unions, and their responsibility for member actions; I’m really now out of my depth, but those curious to learn more might start with this case: Marshall v. INT'L LONGSHOREMEN'S & WAREHOUSEMEN'S U., 371 P. 2d 987 - Cal: Supreme Court 1962 - Google Scholar. Again, the above is not a conclusion that the DAO is definitely not a partnership, just emphasizing that there aren’t clear answers. The Wyoming DAO approach is worth considering, but the center of what that law does is allow certain corporate record keeping and voting to be conducted on-chain (instead of, say, a secretary keeping meeting minutes).  As the article by @MFeinberg points out, it also requires the DAO operating smart contract be mutable.  So I’m not sure the WyomingDAO approach really gets to the core concerns of community members.

0xbocaJ:  Again, the above is not a conclusion that the DAO is definitely not a partnership, just emphasizing that there aren’t clear answers.   Yes, we are in limbo. And even the DAO friendly jurisdictions in the US have to adapt as we see with the tweaks to the Wyoming Statute.

This is a thoughtful post - thanks for adding to the discussion. Economics of externalities and Law/Economics are useful ways to view some of these key issues. People have valid interests in privacy and censorship resistance.  Crypto-currencies add real value here. However people also have valid interests in preventing tax fraud, money laundering, terrorist financing…  crypto currencies can impose potentially significant negative externalities on societies and the society will have to balance the gains from crypto versus the negative externalities imposed on the society.  Ignoring these potential negative externalities will not make the issues or state actions go away.

Great post @jacek  I was wondering why we hadn’t heard much from you at this critical juncture.     jacek:  It has been a year since I was just about to leave my job as the Global Legal Counsel at the Maker Foundation.   I personally hope you will be able to share more knowledge with the DAO in some of the governance debates that are taking place.     jacek:  Unfortunately, not much has happened since then. Regulatory thinking at MakerDAO is driven almost purely by news headlines, and the recent drama on discord around Tornado Cash sanctions is just an example. MakerDAO is reactive, underinformed, sometimes ignorant, and generally susceptible to superficial analyses.   Hopefully smart folks like yourself can chime in more often. For example, there have been some terrible takes regarding the TC situation but this is not helped by the complicated nature of sanctions, even for parties outside the US who happen to be operating in the US market. It is simply not true, for example, that sanctions don’t affect parties outside the US (as anyone who has organised supply chain agreements would know). Sanctions have significant ripple effects and often harm the very same country that issued them. We see that too in the case of TC. It’s an example of what Derrida brilliantly identified as the sometimes destructive autoimmune effects inherent in systems of security and law designed by a body politic to protect itself from “outsiders” and rogues.     jacek:  Stablecoin regulations are being cooked all around the globe. In some cases (EU), they are actually ready.   Back to the main theme here. I agree that the way forward is pretty well set - between FATF guidance and MiCA, more OFAC-type sanctions and the likely stringent regulation of stable-coins in the US, the noose is already tied and slowly tightening. Maybe folks are expecting some form of late-night clemency for crypto but that strikes me as a very weak plan. I’ve assumed that some form of level playing field will be demanded of all DeFi DAOs by nation-states and global organisations (SWIFT, BIS, IMF etc), and it doesn’t really matter if the DAO is fully decentralised or just playing decentralisation theatre. In fact, decentralised theatre acts have a distinct advantage over properly decentralised DAOs. They can respond more quickly and provide undertakings to regulators. They can do deals. They can negotiate. They can compromise. They can simultaneously maintain mutually exclusive beliefs and positions. DAOs cannot do any of these things. A lot of folks forget that most banks and FIs would love to go “full goblin” with their balance sheet, KYC and compliance. They would love to eradicate pesky regulators, banking laws and taxes. They would love to do business in a laissez-faire, permissionless fashion with shady oligarchs and greasy royal families. And moreover, those same banks often do go full goblin and sometimes even get caught. They pay the fines, throw a few key employees under the bus and move on. Banks are in that sense perfected examples of decentralised theatre that we could learn from: to outside observers, they are beholden to boards and shareholders and subject to strict laws and rules but more often than not controlled by a very small internal cabal of profitable revenue whales who make the law in their own image. Why not accept that this is what will happen to Maker DAO? Sure, we can continue lobbying. The crypto industry will get a few wins and concessions along the way of course. Maybe the EU will tweak the rules to benefit some projects. Or the US will concede securities laws only apply to limited cases. DAOs will pocket the cost saving. But as a minimum, DAO/DeFi protocols and platforms need to be ready for the knowable future and engaged in re-shaping it as well. And that means demonstrating that we’ll play by similar rules to everyone else in finance and prove the business case that we offer better outcomes for end-users of all nations. What would be a much stronger play is therefore to prepare, in a very public fashion, for the incoming regs while continuing to strive internally for greater technical resilience, protection of users and privacy. How DAOs navigate this way of doing business should be part of the overall strategy. To choose just one example, it is illustrative to note how Ripple have tried to bridge the gap I’m talking about here. They appear to be one of the few organisations who have the balance about right (and yet they still got into trouble - FinCEN fines in 2016 and now the SEC litigation). They have fought for seats at the table at the key global organisations while keeping in reserve the latent power offered by a permissionless, censorship-resistant, internet-of-value. They appreciate all too well the transformative power to change finance and social structures. We don’t need to agree with Ripple’s organisation, the XRP consensus model, the leadership or questionable founder allocations. Just watch the way they go about their business. What they’re doing is far-reaching and savvy. They are playing a very long game.     jacek:  Ultimately, decentralization is and will be our strongest moat against regulatory risks.   Maybe this is one area where I will part ways with a lot of my cryptolegal colleagues. If the plan is to integrate and re-make financial primitives using composable, decentralised, permissionless tools, then the moat becomes meaningless given how many draw-bridges and interfaces are required to the centralised, permissioned real world. Having a moat implies some type of perimeter between DeFi and everything else. There won’t be such a clear line. Or better said, a clearly definable moat is a sign of weakness, not of strength because it means, to me at least, that DeFi has become trapped by ideologues within an echo-chamber. For starters, who defines “decentralised”? By the above reckoning, decentralisation is that which evades and opposes the laws of the military-industrial complex. Is that evasion really a measure of success for DeFi? Is it a goal we should aspire to? Unless the intent is to remain fugitives for eternity, I say not. But I digress. A moat gives nation-states an easily definable target. It not only locks “them” out, it also locks “us” in. We’ve seen China, India and other large nations concerned about capital flight criminalising crypto transactions and closing on-ramps. We saw the simplest of sanctions against TC, a single protocol, cause chaos across the industry. They are proof of the trivial nature by which crypto can be centrally controlled by nation-states. We need nation-states and their citizens as stakeholders, not enemies. This involves, politics, negotiation and compromise. I don’t know about you, but I’m in the business of bridge building. Recently, I’ve heard that crypto will “lose its soul” as a result of compromise. It’s heart-warming to think digital assets and cryptography have a soul but protecting l’esprit of crypto isn’t a terribly pragmatic or effective strategy. For example, I love vinyl records and tube amplifiers, their warmth and “natural” sound. No one can track my data when I play them. Their use is extremely private. No email marketing or AI suggestions. But they are not the future.     jacek:  This is shadow banking business under a pirate flag. Even if we finally sort out all the current issues in 1-2-3 years, the costs to comply with financial regulations will be enormous.   Maybe I’m suffering the same Kantian fever-dream of a borderless Welt where citizens of the world can travel freely or in this case, transact freely. But at least I recognise that its ambition would require global organisations with support across the industry to not just lobby on its behalf, but to regulate itself. It will need an internationally recognised charter that builds on existing human rights of freedom of association, freedom from arbitrary interference with privacy and the freedom to participate in public affairs. It needs to develop an ethical framework around which development will occur. It needs to work on its trust quotient. The United Metaverse of DeFi. These are achievable goals. It won’t be pretty and it won’t be perfect. But with some work, it will be allow for safe passage for those who develop in this space. If Maker or any other protocol wishes to uphold the pretence that it could sustain a global reserve currency, these are the questions that will need to be reconciled by our industry. If we don’t achieve these goals then I am confident that this technology will be co-opted by organisations who are prepared to make the necessary compromises. Those groups will ultimately win and they know it. We need to get organised.

Was talking today with various folks in discord.  I will mention one by name just to ping him on this subject @brianmcmichael We can talk all we want about the greater picture but I’d like to bring part of this discussion back to earth for all the contractors and delegates at least. Say protocol gets sanctioned and basically the DAO can’t exchange DAI for any currency and people are being arrested and put in jail and require bonds? How is MakerDAO going to be able to respond in different jurisdictions?  With available ‘clean’ funds to say bail people out? With legal counsel? And how if Maker is sanctioned could such funds not come under some sort of freeze or blacklist?

This post reflects exactly my thoughts that I have shared with some MakerDAO enthusiast friends. Regulations on stablecoins are imminent, whether centralized or decentralized, Maker should make the best effort to start preparing. And about RWAs, I have the same opinion as you, they are exposing Maker to a very high risk that it didn’t have before. I’m not aware of the details of the specific RWA CU discussions, but I really hope they are aware of the risks that RWAs bring in relation to possible regulations affecting those assets.
Dai cant be a world reserve currency without being used in the real world. That means payments and lending in RWA.

Yes, thats true but there are also associated risks that come with being a world reserve currency that we are not prepared (IMO). E.g. we are not too big too fail/censor/ban at this time.     TRUEMAKER:  Either we choose or live in limbo.

Why can´t DAI be a reserve currency without lending in RWA? My point is that RWAs means the loss of decentralization of collaterals and risks that those collaterals may be regulated/frozen/blocked by state authorities, which may put the protocol at risk if the RWA has a large scale over the total collateralized assets. Hopefully these risks are considered, because they are greater than the risks experienced with fully decentralized collaterals.

I fully support you, we are practically in a vicious circle, the current incentives are vaults or some loan contract with juicy interest rates that benefit us, these openings decrease as we have already seen, it is imminent that cryptocurrencies will be used on a global scale and stablecoins will be an alternative to CBDC but DAI without real use other than vaults, without adoption by inexperienced people (which will soon dominate the market) will make us get stuck, I know jurisdictions are dangerous when it comes to RWA but it is a necessary evil to increase natural adoption of DAI

It is a good point of view, but the regulations as you said are imminent, DAI although many say that it cannot pass those regulations, the governments only want to have their piece of cake, it does not seem fair to me that we worry about RWA having the entity more centralized and powerful supporting us, plus BlackRock who are practically the owners can make and unmake regulations

Marian:  My point is that RWAs means the loss of decentralization of collaterals and risks that those collaterals may be regulated/frozen/blocked by state authorities, which may put the protocol at risk if the RWA has a large scale over the total collateralized assets. Hopefully these risks are considered, because they are greater than the risks experienced with fully decentralized collaterals.   This is a widely believed sentiment in the community but it is plain wrong. The Tornado Cash example shows quite clearly that on-chain collateral can be blocked or frozen just as easily as off-chain collateral. The more important point is that RWA is already regulated so there is far less chance that there would be any need for a governmental authority to block or freeze it. Unlike Tornado, RWA is much harder to use for money-laundering or sanctions evasion as it is fully KYC’d. Since RWA is KYC’d the authorities would only need to go after specific bad actors and the rest of the RWA issuance would be unaffected.

elidco:  The Tornado Cash example shows quite clearly that on-chain collateral can be blocked or frozen just as easily as off-chain collateral.   In the Tornado Cash case, USDC was frozen, which is a centralized asset, not a decentralized one, issued by a centralized institutions.     elidco:  The more important point is that RWA is already regulated so there is far less chance that there would be any need for a governmental authority to block or freeze it   New regulations can be decided that do not exist today. Hypothesis, a mortgage crisis breaks out and state authorities decide to suspend foreclosures. It would cause great damage to Maker. I´m not saying that these strategies should be left aside, I´m saying that more attention should be paid to them as they involve greater risks than those assumed with decentralized collateral.

Marian:  En el caso Tornado Cash, se congeló USDC, que es un activo centralizado, no descentralizado, emitido por instituciones centralizadas.   Of course, but remember that we have USDC support, if that USDC has a DAI backup connection it could be frozen in the same way, or even when entering a cex it could be automatically frozen because it has a peer-to-peer link     Marian:  Se pueden decidir nuevas regulaciones que hoy no existen. Hipótesis, se desata una crisis hipotecaria y las autoridades estatales deciden suspender las ejecuciones hipotecarias. Causaría un gran daño a Maker. No digo que se dejen de lado estas estrategias, digo que se les debe prestar más atención ya que implican mayores riesgos que los asumidos con garantías descentralizadas.   RWA is another line that branches off, we would not necessarily have a lot of liquidity in mortgages, let’s imagine that RWA is a building, and each loan or action that Maker makes is a room, so imagine how difficult it would be to close each room, the same would not happen with a protocol that includes only USDC, Circle fails and the entire Defi ecosystem collapses but Maker is the one that will look worse, or if Circle takes strict regulatory measures DAI will not be able to pass them with 10 points, then it would also collapse, the idea is to get real liquid to diversify , let us remember diversification is the key to security

Marian:  In the Tornado Cash case, USDC was frozen, which is a centralized asset, not a decentralized one, issued by a centralized institutions.   No. That is not what happened. OFAC put the decentralized Tornado Cash wallets on the sanctions (SDN) list. Circle froze USDC in accounts that interacted with these sanctioned wallets as did a number of DeFi protocols including Uniswap and Aave: DeFi protocols Aave, Uniswap, Balancer, ban users following OFAC sanctions on Tornado Cash     Marian:  New regulations can be decided that do not exist today.   Yes, there will be new regulations, but it is far more likely that Maker and DeFi will be the target of these regulations than the 200 year old mortgage market. Mortgages and mortgage-backed securities continued without new regulation even after the last mortgage crisis in 2008-2009. On the other hand, there are already several bills proposed in Congress to regulate DeFi.

elidco:  Circle froze USDC in accounts that interacted with these sanctioned wallets as did a number of DeFi protocols including Uniswap and Aave: DeFi protocols Aave, Uniswap, Balancer, ban users following OFAC sanctions on Tornado Cash   I think you’re drawing a bit of a false equivalency. Circle actually used the on-chain blacklisting functionality of it’s bespoke ERC-20 smart contract to block the addresses identified by OFAC from sending or receiving tokens. https://etherscan.io/address/0x5db0115f3b72d19cea34dd697cf412ff86dc7e1b. So it’s now actually impossible for the 70k USDC in TC to get out, or for more TC to come in. What the DeFi exchanges did was different. On the one hand, I don’t believe that most of them can effect a block on-chain. Instead, they have modified the front-ends to include a block (though if you have a source that more directly addresses the on vs off chain issue and says I’m wrong, I am open to being told off). But at the same time, their actions have been broader, banning interactions not only from addresses that were named by OFAC, but addresses that interacted with those addresses.

elidco:  Yes, there will be new regulations, but it is far more likely that Maker and DeFi will be the target of these regulations than the 200 year old mortgage market. Mortgages and mortgage-backed securities continued without new regulation even after the last mortgage crisis in 2008-2009. On the other hand, there are already several bills proposed in Congress to regulate DeFi.   this is a good point. many RWAs have been around a long time, address large market needs (housing, auto finance, credit cards, trade finance…) and have significant public support

0xbocaJ:  think you’re drawing a bit of a false equivalency. Circle actually used the on-chain blacklisting functionality of it’s bespoke ERC-20 smart contract to block the addresses identified by OFAC from sending or receiving tokens. https://etherscan.io/address/0x5db0115f3b72d19cea34dd697cf412ff86dc7e1b. So it’s now actually impossible for the 70k USDC in TC to get out, or for more TC to come in.   Yes, I did not go into the detailed differences and I was not trying to make the actions equivalent. The point is that the actual OFAC sanctions were enforced against Tornado Cash - a decentralized protocol. Circle was not sanctioned and there was no overall freeze of USDC (only 75k).
That’s fair enough, and you do raise a good point that even entities that strictly interact with only on-chain assets are substantially effected by government sanctions.

Yes, exactly. Maker should not expect that it can avoid sanctions or sanctions repercussions just because it holds only on-chain assets. My point several posts above is that because RWA is already regulated it is much less likely to be impacted by sanctions than unregulated on-chain assets. There seems to be a misperception in the community than on-chain assets are “safer” than RWA when it is in fact the opposite.

To get a glimpse into the current state of DAI liquidity on DEX, let’s see how much DAI we can buy, At 4000 DAI, we can see there are some price discrepancies, but we can get the DAI liquidity needed and at a good price be that as it may individuals too have substantial interface in anticipating assess extortion, cash washing, psychological militant financing… crypto monetary forms can force possibly noteworthy negative externalities on social orders and the society will got to adjust the picks up from crypto versus the negative externalities forced on the society. Overlooking these potential negative externalities will not make the issues or state activities go absent.

Love posts/threads like this, direct and clear. Thanks, @jacek for bringing these thoughts forward.     0xbocaJ:  I don’t think it’s a foregone conclusion that legal entity status for the DAO necessarily means its a partnership with unlimited liability for all members.   Due to the nature of the system, heavily echo this. Regardless, your point of meeting regulators to educate them on permissionless systems is a useful strategy that could use some more collaboration and unification.  Need a few more @PaperImperium s out there grinding the education circuit.     0xbocaJ:  Picking a favorable jurisdiction for incorporation   I don’t really understand this point, though. The maker foundation existed and, as jacek notes, did a good job of interfacing and steering strategy. Eventually, decentralization was the path, so why…do the dance again? Has something significantly changed that would make this advantageous? Genuinely curious.     Daimon-Law:  If the plan is to integrate and re-make financial primitives using composable, decentralised, permissionless tools, then the moat becomes meaningless given how many draw-bridges and interfaces are required to the centralised, permissioned real world.   This is just great prose, had to highlight it.     Daimon-Law:  require global organisations with support across the industry to not just lobby on its behalf, but to regulate itself. It will need an internationally recognised charter that builds on existing human rights of freedom of association, freedom from arbitrary interference with privacy and the freedom to participate in public affairs. It needs to develop an ethical framework around which development will occur. It needs to work on its trust quotient. The United Metaverse of DeFi.   Sounds like you got the preamble to a constitution going.

0xbocaJ:  I think you’re drawing a bit of a false equivalency. Circle actually used the on-chain blacklisting functionality of it’s bespoke ERC-20 smart contract to block the addresses identified by OFAC from sending or receiving tokens   Yes and that is an important distinction. And like you point out, the DeFi exchanges will find ways. When they are pushed in a corner and facing danger, they tend to try to get very creative. They use a scattershot approach.

Eumenes:  many RWAs have been around a long time, address large market needs (housing, auto finance, credit cards, trade finance…) and have significant public support   This is a good point that isn’t raised enough. I read this  press release earlier today from HVB (thanks @teej for linking):  Travis J. Thompson, Esq. Chairman and CEO of HVB commented: “This is the kind of financial innovation that helps bring stable assets to the Cryptocurrency space and provides real benefits to the U.S. economy by bringing a new funding source to the table that will enable economic growth to continue in the greater Philadelphia market area through expanded commercial lending activities."  That latter bit is key. Rather than going down the path of being a pariah, trying to become impervious to any US regulations/sanctions (likely an impossible task in any case), the better defence may well be a good offence: building economic integrations with broad public support. Just imagine if DeFi had another twenty Makers, with twenty more professional RWA teams building integrations with the real world. Twenty more HVBs explicitly saying that crypto is helping drive economic growth! Crypto is an easy target for regulators and politicians when it’s associated with Ponzi schemes, hacks and money laundering. Each successful real-world financial integration helps shift that narrative, a little more each time. Of course (re the original post) that RWAs are not the “cure for all Maker’s problems”, but they don’t have to be, and as a nice bonus they provide us with some diversification away from crypto exposure.

twblack88:      0xbocaJ:  Picking a favorable jurisdiction for incorporation   I don’t really understand this point, though. The maker foundation existed and, as jacek notes, did a good job of interfacing and steering strategy. Eventually, decentralization was the path, so why…do the dance again? Has something significantly changed that would make this advantageous? Genuinely curious.   Saying “decentralization is the path” as a reason for not forming some sort of corporate identity is placing a big bet on the proposition that no court in any jurisdiction will ever decide that Maker is a legal entity.  And the risk is exacerbated given that the SEC and now OFAC have taken the position that DAOs and the smart contract assets thereof are legal entities. That legal risk has a chilling effect on the community because would-be participants don’t know what DAO or DAO member activities they may or may not be liable for, what states or countries the DAO might expose them to jurisdiction in, or what taxes they owe for DAO profits (or what jurisdiction’s tax code applies to DAO activities! Do DAO members owe taxes for every Dai minted?) Further, not affirmatively picking a particular jurisdiction for and form of incorporation gives a would-be plaintiff or regulator leverage to press the DAO towards whatever they think the worst jurisdiction’s laws would be.  For example, a plaintiff could choose to file suit in the state with an active participant in the DAO and the broadest rules for member liability in an unincorporated association.

@jacek Stablecoin regulations are being cooked all around the globe. Dai and Maker will be outlawed if they don’t follow the requirements. These regulations will be very difficult to comply with without a centralized structure in place. After the UST collapse, one should not expect regulatory differentiation between centralized and decentralized stablecoins. However, counting on RWA as the main collateral was a misconception a few years ago, and still is a misconception in 2022. Maker’s smart contracts are not subject to USDC freezing/blocking. This risk is associated with the inherent censorship risks of RWAs rather than a direct sanctions risk for Maker. We will see further attacks on self-hosted wallets and forcing KYC everywhere, and this is why we should treat decentralization with care.
WaterLily:  Dai and Maker will be outlawed if they don’t follow the requirements.   Outlawed or an outlier unable to scale and thrive.

Thanks for the excellent discussion, everyone. I’ve also received quite a lot of feedback from people outside Maker. That’s just another piece of evidence that many closely monitor what’s happening at MakerDAO and our in-house discussions. One common misunderstanding that I saw was that the post describes the overall legal situation at Maker. That’s not exactly the case. My post was prompted by discussions going on in discord at that time. That said, it’s great to see others contributing with their expertise. Thank you for your input. I enjoyed the comments. Another point I wanted to make is that while I expressed my opinions on some of the topics, my main goal was a little different: to highlight that Maker’s strategic decisions will have legal consequences. Some interpreted my post as taking the position that Dai should depeg from USD. Not really; I am not exactly sure if there is currently a market for a free-floating stablecoin. What I meant is that keeping the peg to a fiat currency is going to have tangible regulatory consequences in at least some key markets. At the very least, Maker should be able to predict these consequences. Also, the post wasn’t directly about the Tornado Cash situation. There are many takeaways, but a major one is that we need to be prepared for nasty regulatory developments. Again, it’s crucial to identify them.
jacek:  to highlight that Maker’s strategic decisions will have legal consequences   Yes, well done and thank you for that. I couldn’t agree more.

What positive possibilities would you see if Maker entered a country with loose enough regulations and urgent capital needs to get out of inflation? Example in some countries of Latin America or North Africa

Since the exit of the Foundation, MakerDAO comfortably lives without any local or any country jurisdiction already. It’s probably wise for various unit leaders to make their place of residence obscure to avoid inadvertent legal nexus. But as is, it’d be hard for any national regulator or court to materially intervene in Maker’s business.
